title: Super Thursday: Bank Split On Rate Increase
text:
View Photo 

The moment interest rates start to rise has moved closer, with the Bank of England’s Monetary Policy Committee (MPC (KOSDAQ: 050540.KQ - news ) ) now split on whether to leave borrowing costs on hold. 
One MPC member, Ian McCafferty voted this month to increase the official bank rate from its current level of 0.5% to 0.75%. 
Although the other eight members of the rate-setting committee voted to leave rates on hold, the Bank signalled that borrowing costs could increase early next year. 
The Bank also indicated that the rates most families pay on their mortgages could go up even sooner, driven higher by the rising cost of funding for UK banks. 
In a dump of information today, known as Super Thursday', the Bank not only announced its rate decision for the month, but also published the minutes and the forecasts underlying its move. 
Official bank rate has been at an all-time low of 0.5% since March 2009. Investors currently expect it to stay there until next February or March, a prediction which was essentially endorsed by the Bank, whose job it is to keep inflation as close as possible to 2%. 
"Were Bank Rate to follow the gently rising path implied by market yields, the Committee judges that demand growth would be sufficient to return inflation to the target within two years," the minutes said. 
The Bank’s signal that rates will soon increase comes despite its prediction that inflation will remain close to zero for the next few months – and will stay lower for longer than expected, due in part to falling oil prices. It also comes in spite of a 3.5% rise in the value of the pound since its last set of major forecasts in May. 
However, the main focus is likely to be on interest rates. Although many economists were expecting two or three, rather than just one, MPC member to vote for higher rates, this is nonetheless the first meeting with a split vote since December. According to the minutes, Mr McCafferty thought that there were risks “of a more significant overshoot of inflation following its return to the target.” 
The minutes also said that whatever happens to official Bank rate, mortgage costs are likely to rise soon, with the gap between mortgage rates and official bank rate expected to widen. 
It said: "banks’ funding costs, an important influence on mortgage rates, had risen since May and it was possible that mortgage rates would shortly begin to rise."
